dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Penicillin, discovered just over a hundred years ago, has saved countless lives, but it's wild to think antimicrobial resistance was detected less than 20 years later.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Penicillin, discovered just over a hundred years ago, has saved countless lives, but it's wild to think antimicrobial resistance was detected less than twenty years later.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The development of antimicrobial medications is undoubtedly one of humankinds most incredible achievements, saving billions of lives in the roughly 100 years since they were first discovered. Yet less than 20 years after penicillin was discovered, antimicrobial resistance (AMR) was first detected.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and now AMR is causing an estimated one million deaths per year—it's a massive public health threat, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and now A M R is causing an estimated one million deaths per year-it's a massive public health threat, honestly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since then, resistance has continued to grow into a major public health threat, causing an estimated 1 million deaths per year, and contributing to millions more.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. That's why the EU General Assembly recently called it one of the world's most urgent health threats, demanding immediate action.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. That's why the E U General Assembly recently called it one of the world's most urgent health threats, demanding immediate action.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Indicating the seriousness of the AMR threat, the United Nations General Assembly recently recognized it as one of the worlds most urgent health threats and demanded immediate action to safeguard the ability to treat diseases and enhance food security.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the U.S. is stepping up with initiatives supporting the WHO's One Health program during that big conference in Jeddah.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the U.S. is stepping up with initiatives supporting the W H O's One Health program during that big conference in Jeddah.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats why the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is announcing a series of initiatives that support the World Health Organizations (WHOs) One Health program during the Fourth High-Level Global Ministerial Conference on AMR, which it is currently hosting in Jeddah.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, the Fourth High-Level Global Ministerial Conference on AMR. It's got the largest number of participating countries ever for this meeting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the Fourth High-Level Global Ministerial Conference on A M R. It's got the largest number of participating countries ever for this meeting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The 2024 AMR conference features the largest number of participating countries in the history of this bi-annual meeting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: What I find really interesting about One Health is its integrated approach—human health, animal health, agriculture, the environment… it's all connected.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What I find really interesting about One Health is its integrated approach-human health, animal health, agriculture, the environment... it's all connected.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: What sets One Health apart from previous AMR resistance efforts is its integrated approach to the crisis. It is designed to drive actions in human health, animal health, agriculture and the environment to ensure that lifesaving antimicrobials continue to be available, while protecting against deadly resistance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And they're pushing for things like equitable access to antibiotics and developing new tools for animal and plant health too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And they're pushing for things like equitable access to antibiotics and developing new tools for animal and plant health too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a group, attending countries are demonstrating their commitment to: Doing a better job of preventing and controlling infections Fully implementing national AMR action plans Taking steps to provide equitable access to antibiotics, and Developing new tools to address the growing challenges in animal and plant health.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: They even agreed on the Jeddah Declaration, which includes setting up a global scientific panel led by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They even agreed on the Jeddah Declaration, which includes setting up a global scientific panel led by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Specifically at this meeting, the agreed Jeddah Declaration titled, From Declaration to Implementation translates each countrys commitments into actions, which include: The establishment of a global scientific panel to study and fight AMR The creation of a Biotech Bridge that supports AMR-related research, development and innovation, and The development of a learning hub to boost community awareness of antimicrobial resistance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oh wow, that's huge. And Dr. Anthony Fauci compared AMR to climate change in terms of its global impact—1.3 million lives lost annually, he said.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh wow, that's huge. And Dr. Anthony Fauci compared A M R to climate change in terms of its global impactminus one point three million lives lost annually, he said.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: World Health Organization Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus has compared antimicrobial resistance (AMR) to climate change in terms of its critical impact on global health. He highlighted the devastating toll of AMR, which currently claims 1.3 million lives annually.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the UN set this ambitious target of a 10% reduction in bacterial AMR deaths by 2030. It's a start, but it's gonna take a lot.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the U N set this ambitious target of a ten percent reduction in bacterial A M R deaths by twenty thirty. It's a start, but it's gonna take a lot.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The UN General Assembly's Political Declaration on AMR has set ambitious targets, including a 10% reduction in deaths from bacterial AMR by 2030, marking a significant step in the global fight against this growing threat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Dr. Tedros emphasized sustainable financing and reducing antimicrobial use in animals by 30%—apparently that could boost global GDP by $14 billion by 2050.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Dr. Tedros emphasized sustainable financing and reducing antimicrobial use in animals by thirty percent-apparently that could boost global G D P by fourteen dollars billion by twenty fifty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dr. Tedros emphasized three key priorities for implementing the declaration: increasing sustainable financing through both domestic and international channels, ensuring equitable access to antimicrobials while preventing misuse, and advancing research and innovation in the field. Notably, he pointed out that reducing antimicrobial use in animals by 30% could potentially increase global GDP by US$14 billion by 2050.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: No kidding? That shows how interconnected health and economics really are. And Saudi Arabia's hosting and leading initiatives too, which is great.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No kidding? That shows how interconnected health and economics really are. And Saudi Arabia's hosting and leading initiatives too, which is great.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dr. Hanan Balkhy, WHO Regional Director for the Eastern Mediterranean, praised Saudi Arabias role as host of the Fourth AMR Ministerial Conference, and for its leadership initiatives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Dr. Maria Van Kerkhove praised their collaborative spirit, saying the Kingdom is stepping up on the world stage to tackle AMR.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Dr. Maria Van Kerkhove praised their collaborative spirit, saying the Kingdom is stepping up on the world stage to tackle A M R.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dr. Hanan Balkhy, WHO Regional Director for the Eastern Mediterranean, praised Saudi Arabias role as host of the Fourth AMR Ministerial Conference, and for its leadership initiatives. She said: The Kingdom is stepping up on the world stage to take on antimicrobial resistance, one of the most important and urgent global public health threats.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the Saudi Health Minister, Fahad bin Abdurrahman Al Jalajel, wrapped up by stressing we need to build partnerships everywhere to eliminate this threat.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the Saudi Health Minister, Fahad bin Abdurrahman Al Jalajel, wrapped up by stressing we need to build partnerships everywhere to eliminate this threat.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: H.E. Fahad bin Abdurrahman Al Jalajel, Saudi Minister of Health, concluded: Antimicrobial resistance represents a serious threat to global public health, and we look forward to working with anyone, anywhere to take on the challenge of eliminating AMR. We must build on current partnerships and forge new alliances to secure the health, safety, environment and economic development the world needs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's encouraging to see so many countries committing, but man, the road ahead is still long.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's encouraging to see so many countries committing, but man, the road ahead is still long.

artist_script:
HostA: Penicillin, discovered just over a hundred years ago, has saved countless lives, but it’s wild to think antimicrobial resistance was detected less than 20 years later.
HostB: Yeah, and now AMR is causing an estimated one million deaths per year—it’s a massive public health threat, honestly.
HostA: Exactly. That’s why the EU General Assembly recently called it one of the world’s most urgent health threats, demanding immediate action.
HostB: And the U.S. is stepping up with initiatives supporting the WHO’s One Health program during that big conference in Jeddah.
HostA: Right, the Fourth High-Level Global Ministerial Conference on AMR. It’s got the largest number of participating countries ever for this meeting.
HostB: What I find really interesting about One Health is its integrated approach—human health, animal health, agriculture, the environment… it’s all connected.
HostA: Totally. And they’re pushing for things like equitable access to antibiotics and developing new tools for animal and plant health too.
HostB: They even agreed on the Jeddah Declaration, which includes setting up a global scientific panel led by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
HostA: Oh wow, that’s huge. And Dr. Anthony Fauci compared AMR to climate change in terms of its global impact—1.3 million lives lost annually, he said.
HostB: Yeah, and the UN set this ambitious target of a 10% reduction in bacterial AMR deaths by 2030. It’s a start, but it’s gonna take a lot.
HostA: Dr. Tedros emphasized sustainable financing and reducing antimicrobial use in animals by 30%—apparently that could boost global GDP by $14 billion by 2050.
HostB: No kidding? That shows how interconnected health and economics really are. And Saudi Arabia’s hosting and leading initiatives too, which is great.
HostA: Dr. Maria Van Kerkhove praised their collaborative spirit, saying the Kingdom is stepping up on the world stage to tackle AMR.
HostB: And the Saudi Health Minister, Fahad bin Abdurrahman Al Jalajel, wrapped up by stressing we need to build partnerships everywhere to eliminate this threat.
HostA: It’s encouraging to see so many countries committing, but man, the road ahead is still long.
